2020 / L200/L200 SPORTERO / EU - Workshop Manual
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > ENGINE CONTROL > GENERAL INFORMATION
GENERAL INFORMATION
For the accelerator system, a common rail fuel injection system has been adopted, eliminating of an accelerator cable.
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > ENGINE CONTROL > ACCELERATOR PEDAL > ACCELERATOR PEDAL REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
cautionNever remove the accelerator pedal cover and connector. If the accelerator pedal cover removed, the accelerator pedal position sensor does not work normally.
Pre-removal and Post-installation Operation
Instrument Panel Under Cover Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 52A - Instrument Lower Panel ).
Removal steps
1.Accelerator pedal position sensor connector connection
2.Accelerator pedal module
>>A<<3.Accelerator pedal arm stopper
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< ACCELERATOR PEDAL ARM STOPPER INSTALLATION
1. Insert the accelerator pedal arm stopper straight into the stud bolt of the body.
Shall not insert the dash pad between stopper and body panel.
2. Install the accelerator pedal arm stopper securely by turning it clockwise until its underside contacts with the body panel.
3. After the installation, slightly pull the accelerator pedal arm stopper by hand to check that it cannot be removed easily (appropriate holding power: 100 N or more).
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > GENERAL INFORMATION
GENERAL INFORMATION
The cruise control system, which provides the constant speed driving without depressing the accelerator pedal at a vehicle speed determined by the driver (within the range from approximately 40 km/h or more).
For this cruise control system, due to the adoption of the common rail fuel control system, the engine-ECU electrically controls the fuel injection system.

Making voltage and resistance measurement during troubleshooting.

  • b: Power circuit inspection
  • c: Power circuit inspection
  • d: Commercial tester connection
MB992006Extra fine probeMaking voltage and resistance measurement during troubleshooting.
MB993015Inspection harness
cautionSince the pin part is thin, be careful not to deform it.
Inspection of the engine-ECU harness side terminal voltage check (small terminal only). <4N14>

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS TROUBLESHOOTING FLOW
DIAGNOSIS TROUBLESHOOTING FLOW
Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Contents of Troubleshooting .
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS FUNCTION
DIAGNOSIS FUNCTION
 
 
METHOD OF READING THE DIAGNOSIS CODE
Use the M.U.T.-III to read the diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Diagnosis Function ).
noteWhen reading the diagnosis code, select the item under "MPI/GDI/DIESEL."
 
 
 
METHOD OF ERASING THE DIAGNOSIS CODE
Use the M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Diagnosis Function ).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > DIAGNOSIS CODE CHART
CHECK CHART FOR DIAGNOSIS CODES
Code No.Diagnosis itemReference page
P1564Abnormal voltage at cruise control switches4N14
4N15
P1571Malfunction of the stop lamp switch system
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P1564: Cruise control switch stuck on error<4N14>
Code No. P1564: Abnormal Voltage at Cruise Control Switches <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
This circuit judges the signals of each switches (cruise control ON/OFF, CANCEL, SET - and RES +) of the cruise control switch. The engine-ECU detects the state of the cruise control switches by sensing the voltages shown below.
  • When all switches are released: 4.7 to 5.0 V
  • When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0 to 0.5 V <Vehicles with speed limiter>
  • When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0.9 to 1.7 V
  • When the CANCEL switch is pressed: 1.9 to 2.7 V
  • When the SET - switch is pressed: 2.9 to 3.6 V
  • When the RES + switch is pressed: 3.8 to 4.5 V
 
 
DIAGNOSIS CODE SET CONDITIONS
  • If the cruise control switches is operated, this diagnosis code will be set when the engine-ECU terminal voltage is different from the standard value.
  • Or, this code is set when the SET - switch or RES + switch is stuck to ON.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switch.
  • Malfunction of the clock spring.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise control ON/OFF switch.
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch.
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch.
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch.
  • Item No. 460: ASLF main switch (Speed limiter ON/OFF switch) <Vehicles with speed limiter>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at cruise control switch connector
(1) Remove the cruise control switch from the steering wheel with the cruise control switch connector connected (Refer to ).
(2) Connect the negative battery terminal that was disconnected when the driver's air bag module was removed.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Do not operate the cruise control switch.
(5) Measure the terminal voltage between cruise control switch connector terminal engine-ECU CNTS line and body earth with cruise control switch connector connected.
OK: 4.7 to 5.0 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the harness wire for short circuit to earth between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and the cruise control switch connector terminal
(1) Check the engine-ECU connector.
(2) Disconnect engine-ECU connector and measure at the harness connector side.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4)
cautionWhen checking the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
Use special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the continuity between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and body earth.
OK: No continuity
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 5. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 6. Check the cruise control switch itself
  • Cruise control switch connector check.
  • Check cruise control switch itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the cruise control switch (Refer to ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 7. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 8. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise control ON/OFF switch.
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch.
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch.
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch.
  • Item No. 460: ASLF main switch (Speed limiter ON/OFF switch) <Vehicles with speed limiter>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Go to Step 10.
 
STEP 10. Perform voltage measurement at cruise control switch connector
(1) Remove the cruise control switch from the steering wheel with the cruise control switch connector connected (Refer to ).
(2) Connect the negative battery terminal that was disconnected when the driver's air bag module was removed.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch with cruise control switch connector connected, and measure the terminal voltage between cruise control switch connector terminal engine-ECU SW- line and body earth.
OK: 0.9 to 1.7 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Go to Step 11.
 
STEP 11. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal SW- and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check earthing line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 12. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 13. Check the cruise control switch itself
  • Cruise control switch connector check.
  • Check cruise control switch itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Replace the cruise control switch (Refer to ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 14. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise control ON/OFF switch.
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch.
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch.
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch.
  • Item No. 460: ASLF main switch (Speed limiter ON/OFF switch) <Vehicles with speed limiter>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 16.
 
STEP 15. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(5) After turning the cruise control system to ON, when 2 minutes or more has elapsed without operating the cruise control switches, use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P1564 set?
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 16.
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
 
STEP 16. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(5) After turning the cruise control system to ON, when 2 minutes or more has elapsed without operating the cruise control switches, use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P1564 set?
Return to Step 1.
The procedure is complete.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P1564: Cruise control switch stuck on error<4N15>
Code No. P1564: Abnormal Voltage at Cruise Control Switches <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
This circuit judges the signals of each switches (speed limiter ON/OFF, cruise control ON/OFF, CANCEL, SET - and RES +) of the cruise control switch. The engine-ECU detects the state of the cruise control switches by sensing the voltages shown below.
  • When all switches are released: 4.7 to 5.0 V
  • When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0.9 to 1.7 V
  • When the CANCEL switch is pressed: 1.9 to 2.7 V
  • When the SET - switch is pressed: 2.9 to 3.6 V
  • When the RES + switch is pressed: 3.8 to 4.5 V
 
 
DIAGNOSIS CODE SET CONDITIONS
  • If the cruise control switches is operated, this diagnosis code will be set when the engine-ECU terminal voltage is different from the standard value.
  • Or, this code is set when the SET - switch or RES + switch is stuck to ON.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switch.
  • Malfunction of the clock spring.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise control ON/OFF switch.
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch.
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch.
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at cruise control switch connector
(1) Remove the cruise control switch from the steering wheel with the cruise control switch connector connected (Refer to ).
(2) Connect the negative battery terminal that was disconnected when the driver's air bag module was removed.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Do not operate the cruise control switch.
(5) Measure the terminal voltage between cruise control switch connector terminal engine-ECU CNTS line and body earth with cruise control switch connector connected.
OK: 4.7 to 5.0 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
(1) Remove the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ).
(2) Connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) between the engine-ECU and the body-side harness connector.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Do not operate the cruise control switch.
(5) Measure the terminal voltage between special tool 58-pin connector terminal No. 139 (engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS) and body earth.
OK: 4.7 to 5.0 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the harness wire for short circuit to earth between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and the cruise control switch connector terminal
(1) Check the engine-ECU connector.
(2) Disconnect engine-ECU connector and measure at the harness connector side.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Measure the continuity between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and body earth.
OK: No continuity
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 18.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 6. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 7. Check the cruise control switch itself
  • Cruise control switch connector check.
  • Check cruise control switch itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Replace the cruise control switches (Refer to ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 8. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal CNTS and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 9. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 10. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Go to Step 11.
 
STEP 11. Perform voltage measurement at cruise control switch connector
(1) Remove the cruise control switch from the steering wheel with the cruise control switch connector connected (Refer to ).
(2) Connect the negative battery terminal that was disconnected when the driver's air bag module was removed.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch with cruise control switch connector connected, and measure the terminal voltage between cruise control switch connector terminal engine-ECU SW- line and body earth.
OK: 0.9 to 1.7 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Go to Step 12.
 
STEP 12. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
(1) Remove the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ).
(2) Connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) between the engine-ECU and the body-side harness connector.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch, and measure the terminal voltage between special tool 58-pin connector terminal No.154 (engine-ECU connector terminal SW-) and body earth.
OK: 0.9 to 1.7 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Go to Step 18.
 
STEP 13. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal SW- and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check earthing line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 14. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 18.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 15. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal SW- and clock spring connector terminal, and between clock spring connector terminal and cruise control switch connector terminal
Check earthing line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 16. Check the clock spring itself
  • Clock spring connector check.
  • Check clock spring itself (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 17.
Replace the clock spring and install the driver’s air bag module (Refer to GROUP 52B - Driver’s Air Bag Module and Clock Spring ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 17. Check the cruise control switch itself
  • Cruise control switch connector check.
  • Check cruise control switch itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 18.
Replace the cruise control switches (Refer to ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 18. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 20.
 
STEP 19. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(5) After turning the cruise control system to ON, when 2 minutes or more has elapsed without operating the cruise control switches, use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P1564 set?
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 20.
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
 
STEP 20. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 21.
Return to Step 2.
 
STEP 21. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(5) After turning the cruise control system to ON, when 2 minutes or more has elapsed without operating the cruise control switches, use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P1564 set?
Return to Step 1.
The procedure is complete.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P1571: Brake lamp switch system
Code No. P1571: Malfunction of the Stop Lamp Switch System
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • For the stop lamp switch, 2 switches, a stop lamp switch for the stop lamp illumination and a brake switch exclusively for the cruise control system, are incorporated to improve the reliability.
  • As for the stop lamp switch, when the brake pedal is depressed/released, the stop lamp switch ON/OFF signal is transmitted from the ETACS-ECU to the engine-ECU via CAN bus line.
  • As for the brake switch, the engine-ECU connector terminal BRK monitor the state of the brake switch. The brake switch turn ON/OFF when the brake pedal is depressed/released, and the input signal to the engine-ECU connector terminal BRK changes. According to this change, the engine-ECU judges the state of the brake switch.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS CODE SET CONDITIONS
Check Condition
  • The cruise control indicator lamp illuminates.
Judgement Criteria
  • Open/short in stop lamp switch circuit.
  • Open circuit in the brake switch circuit (between engine-ECU connector terminal BRK and earth).
  • Malfunction of CAN bus line.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the fuse.
  • Malfunction of the stop lamp switch.
  • Malfunction of the ETACS-ECU.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 135: Brake lamp switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the stop lamp operation
Check the stop lamp operation.
OK:
  • Brake pedal depressed: Stop lamp will illuminate
  • Brake pedal not depressed: Stop lamp does not illuminate
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Check the stop lamp system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Rear Combination Lamp, Symptom Procedures, Inspection Procedure 2: The stop lamps do not illuminate or go out normally ). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 4. Check the ETACS system data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the ETACS system data list (Refer to GROUP 54A - ETACS, Troubleshooting, data list reference table ).
  • Item No. 290: Stop lamp switch
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the ETACS-ECU (Refer to GROUP 54A - ETACS, ETACS-ECU ). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 135: Brake lamp switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 6. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 134: Normally closed brake switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal BRK and stop lamp switch connector terminal, and between stop lamp switch connector terminal and earth
Check connector or harness wire for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 8. Check the stop lamp switch itself
  • Stop lamp switch connector check.
  • Check stop lamp switch itself (Refer to GROUP 35A - Brake Pedal, Inspection, Stop Lamp Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the stop lamp switch (Refer to GROUP 35A - Brake Pedal ). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 10. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, and press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(4) With the cruise control switches not operated, depress the brake pedal for several seconds, and then read the diagnosis code of the cruise control system.
Is diagnosis code No. P1571 set?
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 11.
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
 
STEP 11. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 134: Normally closed brake switch.
  • Item No. 135: Brake lamp switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Return to Step 2.
 
STEP 12. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, and press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (the cruise control indicator lamp is turned on).
(4) With the cruise control switches not operated, depress the brake pedal for several seconds, and then read the diagnosis code of the cruise control system.
Is diagnosis code No. P1571 set?
Return to Step 1.
The procedure is complete.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM CHART
CHECK CHART FOR TROUBLE SYMPTOMS
Trouble symptomInspection procedure No.Reference page
Communication with M.U.T.-III is not possible.Communication with the engine-ECU only is impossible.-GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Symptom Procedures, Inspection Procedure 1 .
When the brake pedal is depressed, cruise control is not cancelled.1
When the clutch pedal is depressed, cruise control is not cancelled. <M/T>2
When the selector lever is set to "N" position, cruise control is not cancelled. <A/T>3
When the "CANCEL" switch is pressed, cruise control is not cancelled.4
Cruise control cannot be set (No response "SET/ -" switch and "RES/ +" switch is pressed).5
Hunting (repeated acceleration and deceleration) occurs at the set vehicle speed. 6
When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is turned ON, the cruise control indicator lamp does not illuminate (However, the cruise control system is normal).7
When the cruise control switch is operated, the system is not turned ON.8
When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is turned ON, the speed limiter display screen does not display (However, the cruise control system is normal). <Vehicles with speed limiter>9
When the speed limiter switch is operated, the system is not turned ON. <Vehicles with speed limiter>10
The speed limiter is not deactivated when the accelerator pedal is depressed fully. <Vehicles with speed limiter>11
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN BRAKE PEDAL IS DEPRESSED, CRUISE CONTROL IS NOT CANCELLED
Inspection Procedure 1: When the Brake Pedal is Depressed, Cruise Control is not Cancelled
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
  • Malfunction of CAN bus line.
  • The stop lamp switch circuit is suspected.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the stop lamp switch.
  • Malfunction of the ETACS-ECU.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 4.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 134: Brake switch
  • Item No. 135: Stop lamp switch
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Check the stop lamp switch system (Refer to Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No. P1571: Malfunction of the stop lamp switch system ). Then go to Step 4 .
 
STEP 3. Check the symptom
When the brake pedal is depressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
When the brake pedal is depressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN CLUTCH PEDAL IS DEPRESSED, CRUISE CONTROL IS NOT CANCELLED<M/T>
Inspection Procedure 2: When the Clutch Pedal is Depressed, Cruise Control is not Cancelled <M/T>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Engine-ECU connector terminal CLT1 monitors the clutch switch state.
  • The clutch switch turns ON/OFF when the clutch pedal is depressed/released, and the input signal to the engine-ECU changes. According to this change, the engine-ECU judges the clutch switch status.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The cause is probably a malfunction of the clutch switch circuit.
 
 
POSSIBLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the clutch switch.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 131: MT clutch switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5
Go to Step 2
 
STEP 2. Check the harness wire between engine-ECU connector terminal CLT1 and clutch switch connector terminal, and between clutch switch connector terminal and earth
Check connector or harness wire for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire. Then go to Step 6.
 
STEP 3. Check the clutch switch itself
  • Clutch switch connector check.
  • Check clutch switch itself (Refer to GROUP 21A - On-vehicle Service, Clutch Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the clutch switch (Refer to GROUP 21A - Clutch Pedal ). Then go to Step 6.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 131: MT clutch switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 6.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
When the clutch pedal is depressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check the symptom
When the clutch pedal is depressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN SELECTOR LEVER IS MOVED TO "N" POSITION, CRUISE CONTROL IS NOT CANCELLED<A/T>
Inspection Procedure 3: When the Selector Lever is Set to "N" Position, Cruise Control is not Cancelled <A/T>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
When the selector lever is operated, the selector lever position signal from the inhibitor switch is sent to the A/T-ECU. Engine-ECU receives the selector lever position signal from the A/T-ECU via the CAN bus line.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
  • Malfunction of CAN bus line.
  • The inhibitor switch circuit is suspected.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the inhibitor switch.
  • Malfunction of the A/T-ECU.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 42: Neutral switch
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Check the inhibitor switch system [Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting <A/T>, Diagnosis Code Procedures Code No. P0707: Inhibitor Switch System (Open Circuit) , Code No. P0708: Inhibitor Switch System (Short Circuit) ]. Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 3. Check the A/T system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check A/T system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting <A/T>, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the A/T system (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting <A/T>, Diagnosis Code Chart ). Then go to Step 5.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
When the selector lever is set to "N" position, is the cruise control cancelled?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
When the selector lever is set to "N" position, is the cruise control cancelled?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN "CANCEL" SWITCH IS TURNED ON, CRUISE CONTROL IS NOT CANCELLED
Inspection Procedure 4: When the CANCEL Switch is Pressed, Cruise Control is not Cancelled
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The cause is probably an open-circuit in the circuit inside the CANCEL switch.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switches.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Check the cruise control switch system (Refer to Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No. P1564: Abnormal voltage at cruise control switch <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 3.
 
STEP 2. Check the symptom
When the CANCEL switch is pressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the symptom
When the CANCEL switch is pressed, is the cruise control cancelled?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > CRUISE CONTROL CANNOT BE SET.
Inspection Procedure 5: Cruise Control cannot be Set (No Response SET - Switch and RES + Switch is Pressed)
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The fail-safe function is probably cancelling cruise control system. In this case, checking the cruise control system, diesel fuel system, ASTC system, CAN bus system and A/T system diagnosis codes. The M.U.T.-III can also be used to check if the circuits of each input switch are normal or not by checking the data list.
notePress the cruise control switches one by one securely. Otherwise, the cruise control system may not be started.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Malfunction of the diesel fuel system.
  • Malfunction of the ASTC system.
  • Malfunction of the A/T system <A/T>.
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switches.
  • Malfunction of the stop lamp switch.
  • Malfunction of the clutch switch <M/T>.
  • Malfunction of the inhibitor switch <A/T>.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 2. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Trouble Code ). Then go to Step 11 .
Go to Step 3 <A/T>
Go to Step 4<M/T>.
 
STEP 3. Check the A/T system diagnosis code <A/T>
Use M.U.T.-III to check A/T system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the A/T system (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ). Then go to Step 11.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the ASTC system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check ASTC system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 35C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the ASTC system (Refer to GROUP 35C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ). Then go to Step 11.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the diagnosis code
(1) Use the M.U.T.-III, erase the diagnosis code of the cruise control system.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, and press the cruise control ON/OFF switch to turn the cruise control system to ON (turn ON the cruise control indicator lamp).
(3) After turning the cruise control system to ON, when 2 minutes or more has elapsed without operating the cruise control switches.
(4) With the cruise control switches not operated, depress the brake pedal for several seconds, and then read the diagnosis code of the cruise control system.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the cruise control system (Refer to ). Then go to Step 11.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Check the cruise control switch system (Refer to Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No. P1564: Abnormal voltage at cruise control switch <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 134: Normally closed brake switch.
  • Item No. 135: Brake lamp switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8 <M/T>
Go to Step 9 <A/T>
Refer to Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No.P1571: Stop lamp switch system . Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list <M/T>
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 131: MT clutch switch.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Refer to Symptom Procedures, Inspection Procedure 2 . Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list <A/T>
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 42: Neutral switch
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Check the inhibitor switch system [Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Procedures Code No. P0707: Inhibitor Switch System (Open Circuit) , Code No. P0708: Inhibitor Switch System (Short Circuit) ]. Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 10. Check the symptom
Can cruise control be set?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 11.
 
STEP 11. Check the symptom
Can cruise control be set?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > HUNTING (REPEATED ACCELERATION AND DECELERATION) OCCURS AT THE SET VEHICLE SPEED
Inspection Procedure 6: Hunting (Repeated Acceleration and Deceleration) Occurs at the Set Vehicle Speed
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
  • The wheel speed sensor signal (vehicle speed signal) or the diesel fuel system is suspected.
  • The wheel speed sensor signal (vehicle speed signal) is transmitted from the ASTC-ECU to the engine-ECU via the CAN bus line.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Malfunction of the ASTC system.
  • Malfunction of the A/T system.
  • Malfunction of the diesel fuel system.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 7.
 
STEP 2. Check the ASTC system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check ASTC system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 35C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the ASTC system (Refer to GROUP 35C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ). Then go to Step 7.
Go to Step 4 <M/T>.
Go to Step 3 <A/T>.
 
STEP 3. Check the A/T system diagnosis code <A/T>
Use M.U.T.-III to check A/T system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the A/T system (Refer to GROUP 23C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ). Then go to Step 7.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Trouble Code ). Then go to Step 7.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 04: Vehicle speed.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 7.
 
STEP 6. Check the symptom
Does a hunting occur?
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 7.
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
 
STEP 7. Check the symptom
Does a hunting occur?
Return to Step 1.
The procedure is complete.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > CRUISE CONTROL INDICATOR LIGHT INSIDE COMBINATION METER DOES NOT ILLUMINATE (HOWEVER, CRUISE CONTROL IS NORMAL).
Inspection Procedure 7: When the Cruise Control ON/OFF Switch is Turned ON, the Cruise Control Indicator Lamp does not Illuminate (However, the Cruise Control System is Normal)
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The engine-ECU detects cruise control ON/OFF switch ON signal to illuminate the cruise control indicator lamp within the combination meter.
  • The cruise control indicator lamp illuminate signal is transmitted from the engine-ECU to the combination meter via CAN bus line.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
  • The CAN bus line between the engine-ECU and the combination meter may be defective.
  • The combination meter or engine-ECU may also be defective.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the combination meter.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 2. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is diagnosis code No. U1108 set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No.U1108: combination meter Time-out ). Then go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the combination meter system actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to the combination meter system actuator test (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Troubleshooting, Actuator Test Table ).
  • Item No. 7: Indicator1
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair the combination meter system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Trouble Symptom Chart ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is turned ON, is the cruise control indicator lamp illuminated?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is turned ON, is the cruise control indicator lamp illuminated?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > When the cruise control switch is operated, the system is not turned on.
Inspection Procedure 8: When The Cruise Control Switch is Operated, The System is not Turned ON
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
This circuit judges the signals of each switches (speed limiter ON/OFF, cruise control ON/OFF, CANCEL, SET - and RES +) of the cruise control switches. The engine-ECU detects the state of the cruise control switches by sensing the voltages shown below.
  • When all switches are released: 4.7 to 5.0 V
  • When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0 to 0.5 V <Vehicles with speed limiter>
  • When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0.9 to 1.7 V
  • When the CANCEL switch is pressed: 1.9 to 2.7 V
  • When the SET - switch is pressed: 2.9 to 3.6 V
  • When the RES + switch is pressed: 3.8 to 4.5 V
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The M.U.T.-III can also be used to check if the circuits of each input switches are normal or not by checking the data list.
notePress the cruise control switches one by one securely. Otherwise, the cruise control system may not be started.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switches.
  • Malfunction of the clock spring.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Code ). Then go to Step 5.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
  • Item No. 460: ASLF main switch (Speed limiter ON/OFF switch) <Vehicles with speed limiter>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the cruise control switches
Refer to .
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the cruise control switches (Refer to ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
Is the system turned on by operating the cruise control switch?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU <4N14> or <4N15>). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
Is the system turned on by operating the cruise control switch?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > SPEED LIMITER DISPLAY SCREEN INSIDE COMBINATION METER DOES NOT DISPLAY (HOWEVER, CRUISE CONTROL SYSTEM IS NORMAL).<Vehicoles with speed limiter>
Inspection Procedure 9: When The Speed Limiter ON/OFF Switch is Turned ON, The Speed limiter Display Screen does not Display (However, the Speed Limiter System is Normal) <Vehicles with Speed Limiter>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The engine-ECU detects speed limiter ON/OFF switch ON signal to display the speed limiter display screen on the multi information display in the combination meter.
  • The speed limiter display screen ON signal is transmitted from the engine-ECU to the combination meter via CAN bus line.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
  • The CAN bus line between the engine-ECU and the combination meter may be defective.
  • The combination meter or engine-ECU may also be defective.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Malfunction of CAN bus system.
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the combination meter.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
caution
  • If there is any problem in the CAN bus lines, an incorrect diagnosis code may be set. Prior to this diagnosis, diagnose the CAN bus lines.
  • Before replacing the ECU, ensure that the CAN bus lines is normal.
STEP 1. Check the CAN bus system diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus diagnosis (Refer to GROUP 54C - Explanation About The M.U.T.-III Can Bus Diagnostics ).
Is the check result satisfactory?
Go to Step 2.
Repair the CAN bus lines (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting, Can Bus Diagnostic Table ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 2. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is diagnosis code No. U01108 set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Procedures, Code No. U1108: combination meter Time-out ). Then go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the combination meter system actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to the combination meter system actuator test (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Troubleshooting, Actuator Test Table ).
  • Item No. 2: LCD (AUTO)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair the combination meter system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Trouble Symptom Chart ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is turned ON, is the speed limiter display screen displayed?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is turned ON, is the speed limiter display screen displayed?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN THE SPEED LIMITER SWITCH IS OPERATED, THE SYSTEM IS NOT TURNED ON.<Vehicoles with speed limiter>
Inspection Procedure 10: When The Speed Limiter Switch is Operated, The System is not Turned ON <Vehicles with Speed Limiter>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
This circuit judges the signals of each switches (speed limiter ON/OFF, cruise control ON/OFF, CANCEL, SET - and RES +) of the cruise control switches. The engine-ECU detects the state of the cruise control switches by sensing the voltages shown below.
  • When all switches are released: 4.7 to 5.0 V
  • When the speed limiter ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0 to 0.5 V <Vehicles with speed limiter>
  • When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is pressed: 0.9 to 1.7 V
  • When the CANCEL switch is pressed: 1.9 to 2.7 V
  • When the SET - switch is pressed: 2.9 to 3.6 V
  • When the RES + switch is pressed: 3.8 to 4.5 V
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The M.U.T.-III can also be used to check if the circuits of each input switches are normal or not by checking the data list.
notePress the cruise control switches one by one securely. Otherwise, the cruise control system may not be started.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the cruise control switches.
  • Malfunction of the clock spring.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Code ). Then go to Step 5.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 136: Cruise main switch (Cruise control ON/OFF switch)
  • Item No. 137: Cruise cancel switch (CANCEL switch)
  • Item No. 138: Cruise set switch (SET - switch)
  • Item No. 139: Cruise resume switch (RES + switch)
  • Item No. 460: ASLF main switch (Speed limiter ON/OFF switch)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check the cruise control switches
Refer to .
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the cruise control switches (Refer to ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
Is the system turned on by operating the speed limiter switch?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the symptom
Is the system turned on by operating the speed limiter switch?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHEN KICKDOWN IS DEPRESSED, SPEED LIMITER IS NOT CANCELLED<Vehicoles with speed limiter>
Inspection Procedure 11: The Speed Limiter is not Deactivated when the Accelerator Pedal is Depressed Fully <Vehicles with Speed Limiter>
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The accelerator pedal position sensor or engine-ECU may also be defective.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Damaged harness or connector.
  • Malfunction of the accelerator pedal position sensor.
  • Malfunction of the engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check the diesel fuel system diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check diesel fuel system diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Function ).
Is any diagnosis code set?
Repair the diesel fuel system (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Code ). Then go to Step 4.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check the diesel fuel system data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diesel fuel system data list (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Data List Reference Table ).
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
OK: Approximately 4.33 V or more (Depress the accelerator pedal fully)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Replace the accelerator pedal assembly (Refer to ). Then go to Step 4.
 
STEP 3. Check the symptom
Is the speed limiter deactivated when the accelerator pedal is depressed fully?
It can be assumed that this malfunction is intermittent (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunction ).
Replace the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ). Then go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the symptom
Is the speed limiter deactivated when the accelerator pedal is depressed fully?
The procedure is complete.
Return to Step 1.

caution
  • Road test always needs 2 people: 1 driver and 1 observer.
  • When shifting the selector lever to "D" position the brakes should be applied so that the vehicle does not move forward.

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > CHECK AT ECU TERMINAL<4N14>
CHECK AT ENGINE-ECU TERMINAL <4N14>
 
 
Terminal Voltage Check Chart
noteThe voltage cannot be measured because the engine-ECU cannot be backprobed. This is only a list of references.
Engine-ECU connector terminal arrangement
Terminal No.Terminal codeCheck itemCheck conditionNormal condition
95CNTSCruise control switchIgnition switch: "ON"All switches: Released4.7 to 5.0 V
Speed limiter ON/OFF switch: Pressed
<Vehicles with speed limiter>
0 to 0.5 V
Cruise control ON/OFF switch: Pressed0.9 to 1.7 V
CANCEL switch: Pressed1.9 to 2.7 V
SET - switch: Pressed2.9 to 3.6 V
RES + switch: Pressed3.8 to 4.5 V
147CLT1Clutch switch <M/T>Ignition switch: "ON"Release the clutch pedal.1 V or less
Depress the clutch pedal.10 V or more
160BRKStop lamp switch (brake switch)Ignition switch: "ON"Depress the brake pedal.System voltage
Release the brake pedal.1V or less
 
 
Check Chart for Resistance and Continuity Between Terminals
1. Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
2. Disconnect the engine-ECU connector.
3. Measure the resistance and check for continuity between the terminals of the engine-ECU harness-side connector while referring to the check chart.
note
  1. When measuring resistance and checking continuity, a harness for checking contact pin pressure should be used instead of inserting a test probe.
  2. The chart procedures do not have the particular order.
cautionIf the terminals that should be checked are mistaken, or if connector terminals are not correctly shorted to body earth, damage may be caused to the vehicle wiring, sensors, engine-ECU and/or ohmmeter. Be careful to prevent this!
4. If the ohmmeter shows any deviation from the standard value, check the corresponding sensor, actuator and related electrical wiring, and the repair or replace.
5. After repair or replacement, recheck with the ohmmeter to confirm that the repair or replacement has corrected the problem.
Terminal No.Terminal codeInspection itemNormal condition (Check condition)
44 - Body earthGNDE - Body earthEngine-ECU earthContinuity (2 Ω or less)
45 - Body earthGNDB - Body earth
161 - Body earthSGND - Body earth
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > CHECK AT ECU TERMINAL<4N15>
CHECK AT ENGINE-ECU TERMINAL <4N15>
 
 
Terminal Voltage Check Chart
Use special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291), check the engine-ECU terminal voltage.
1. Remove the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ).
2. Connect the special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) between the engine-ECU and the body-side harness connector.
3. Measure the voltages between the check connector terminals of the special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) and earth terminals No. 116, 117 or 145.
 

 
 
Engine-ECU connector terminal arrangement
Terminal No.Terminal codeCheck itemCheck conditionNormal condition

Release the brake pedal.1V or less
112CLT1Clutch switch <M/T>Ignition switch: "ON"Release the clutch pedal.1 V or less
Depress the clutch pedal.10 V or more

Cruise control ON/OFF switch: Pressed0.9 to 1.7 V
CANCEL switch: Pressed1.9 to 2.7 V
SET - switch: Pressed2.9 to 3.6 V
RES + switch: Pressed3.8 to 4.5 V
 
 
Check Chart for Resistance and Continuity Between Terminals
Use special tool MB992291, measure the resistance and check for continuity between the terminals of the engine-ECU harness-side connector
1. Remove the engine-ECU (Refer to GROUP 13A - Engine-ECU ).
2. Connect the special tool MB992291 between the engine-ECU and the body-side harness connector.
3. Measure the resistance and check for continuity between the terminals of the engine-ECU harness-side connector while referring to the check chart.

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > CRUISE CONTROL SYSTEM OPERATION CHECK
CRUISE CONTROL SYSTEM OPERATION CHECK
 
 
Cruise Control ON/OFF Switch Check
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch of the cruise control switches, and check that the cruise control indicator lamp within the combination meter illuminates.
3. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch again, and check that the cruise control indicator lamp within the combination meter goes out.
 
 
 
Speed Limiter ON/OFF Switch Check <Vehicles with Speed Limiter>
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch of the cruise control switches, and check that the speed limiter display screen is displayed on the multi information display in the combination meter.
3. Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch again, and check that the speed limiter display screen goes out.
 
 
 
Cruise Control Setting
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, cruise control indicator lamp: illuminated). Or Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, speed limiter display screen: display).
3. Drive at the desired speed within the range of approximately 40 km/h or more.
4. Push the SET - switch.
5. Check to be sure that when the SET - switch is released the speed is the desired constant speed. The speed limiter will store a set vehicle speed, and then regulate the vehicle speed within that stored speed.
noteIf the vehicle speed decreases to approximately 15 km/h below the set speed because of climbing a hill for example, it is normal for the cruise control to be cancelled. When the vehicle speed is decelerated to the low speed limit (approximately 40 km/h) or less, the constant speed driving will be cancelled even if the vehicle speed is not decelerated 15 km/h or more from the set speed.
 
 
 
Speed-increase Setting
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, cruise control indicator lamp: illuminated). Or Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, speed limiter display screen: display).
3. Set to the desired speed within the range of approximately 40 km/h or more.
4. Push the RES + switch.
5. Check to be sure that acceleration continues while the RES + switch is pushed, and that the speed at the time it was released becomes the constant driving speed. Every time the RES + switch is pressed briefly, the speed limiter will store a vehicle speed. The speed limiter will regulate the vehicle speed within that last stored speed.
noteAcceleration can be continued even if the vehicle speed has passed the high speed limit. But the constant driving speed when the RES + switch is released will be recorded as the high speed limit.
 
 
 
Speed-reduction Setting
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, cruise control indicator lamp: illuminated). Or Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, speed limiter display screen: display).
3. Set to the desired speed within the range of approximately 40 km/h or more.
4. Push the SET - switch.
5. Check to be sure that deceleration continues while the SET - switch is pushed, and that the speed at the time it was released becomes the constant driving speed. Every time the SET - switch is pressed briefly, the speed limiter will store a vehicle speed. The speed limiter will regulate the vehicle speed within that last stored speed.
 
 
 
Return to the Set Speed Before Cancellation and Cruise Control Cancellation
1. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
2. Push the cruise control ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, cruise control indicator lamp: illuminated). Or Push the speed limiter ON/OFF switch (cruise control system: ON, speed limiter display screen: display).
3. Set to the desired speed within the range of approximately 40 km/h or more.
4. When any of the following operations are performed while at constant speed during cruise control, check if normal driving is resumed and deceleration occurs. Check that the speed limiter is deactivated by pressing the CANCEL switch.
noteThe accelerator pedal must NOT be depressed.
(1) The CANCEL switch is pushed.
(2) The brake pedal is depressed.
5. At a vehicle speed of the low speed limit (approximately 40 km/h) or higher, check if when the RES + switch is pushed, the vehicle speed returns to the speed before cruise control driving was cancelled, and constant speed driving occurs.
6. When the cruise control ON/OFF switch is pushed again (cruise control system: OFF) while driving at constant speed, check if normal driving is resumed and deceleration occurs.
noteThe accelerator pedal must NOT be depressed.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > CRUISE CONTROL SYSTEM COMPONENT CHECK
CRUISE CONTROL SYSTEM COMPONENT CHECK
 
 
Cruise Control Switch Check
1. Remove the cruise control switch (Refer to ).
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 5 and terminal No. 6 when each of the speed limiter ON/OFF <vehicles with speed limiter>, cruise control ON/OFF, CANCEL, SET - and RES + switches is pressed. If the values measured at the time each switch is pressed correspond to those in the table below, the resistance values are correct.
 
Terminal connector of testerSwitch positionSpecified condition
5 - 6All switches are released.Open circuit
Speed limiter ON/OFF switch is pressed
<Vehicles with speed limiter>
Continuity (less than 2Ω)
Cruise control ON/OFF switch is pressed176 to 180 Ω
CANCEL switch is pressed460 to 470 Ω
SET - switch is pressed1,030 to 1,051 Ω
RES + switch is pressed2,725 to 2,837 Ω
3. Check that illumination of the cruise control switch turns on when the battery positive terminal is connected to cruise control switch connector terminal No. 3, and the battery negative terminal is connected to cruise control switch connector terminal No. 1.
 
 
 
Stop Lamp Switch Check
Refer to GROUP 35A - Brake Pedal, Inspection, Stop Lamp Switch Check .
 
 
 
Clutch Switch Check <M/T>
Refer to GROUP 21A - On-vehicle Service, Clutch Switch Check .
 
 
 
Inhibitor Switch ("N" Position) Check <A/T>
Refer to GROUP 23C - On-vehicle Service, Essential Service, Inhibitor Switch Continuity Check .
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL > CRUISE CONTROL SWITCH > CRUISE CONTROL SWITCH REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
For the cruise control switch removal and installation procedures, refer to GROUP 37 - Steering Wheel .
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > GENERAL INFORMATION
GENERAL INFORMATION
The emission control system consists of the following subsystems:
  • Exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) system
  • Diesel particulate filter (DPF) system
  • Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system <4N14>
  • Emission reduction system
ItemNameSpecification
EGR system (Purpose: NOx reduction)EGR valveDC motor type
EGR valve position sensorHall element type
EGR coolerWater cooled type
EGR cooler bypass valve solenoid valveON/OFF type solenoid valve
EGR gas temperature sensorThermistor type
DPF system (Purpose: PM removal)DPFClosed type
No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensorThermistor type
No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)Thermistor type
No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature)Thermistor type
Exhaust differential pressure sensorPiezo resistive semiconductor type
SCR system <4N14> (Purpose: NOx reduction)SCRAmmonia adsorption type
No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensorZirconia type
No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensorZirconia type
Exhaust muffler PM sensorResistance detection type
Urea pump moduleDual pump type
Urea injector assemblyElectromagnetic type
Emission reduction systemsFuel injection control (Purpose: PM reduction)Common rail type
Catalytic converter (Purpose: CO, HC reduction)Monolith type
