17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > VACUUM HOSE > VACUUM CIRCUIT DIAGRAM
VACUUM CIRCUIT DIAGRAM
<4N14>
<4N15>
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > VACUUM HOSE > VACUUM HOSE CHECK
VACUUM HOSE CHECK
1. Using the vacuum circuit diagram as a guide, check to be sure that the vacuum hoses are correctly connected.
2. Check the connection condition of the vacuum hoses which can be removed, loosened, clogged possibly. And then check whether there are no folded and damaged vacuum hoses.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > VACUUM HOSE > VACUUM HOSE INSTALLATION
VACUUM HOSE INSTALLATION
1. When connecting the vacuum hoses, they should be securely inserted onto the nipples.
2. Connect the hoses correctly, using the vacuum circuit diagram as a guide.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > GENERAL INFORMATION (EGR SYSTEM)
GENERAL INFORMATION (EGR SYSTEM)
The electronically controlled EGR system consists of an EGR valve, engine-ECU and sensors.
The EGR valve aims at reducing the amount of NOx (nitric oxide) discharge that increases with the rise in the exhaust gas temperature. Also, the EGR cooler bypass system is employed. By blocking the exhaust gas flow not to pass through the EGR cooler at the engine cold state, HC (hydrocarbon) emissions are reduced. Thus, the engine-ECU optimally controls the exhaust gas temperature in accordance with the operating conditions of the engine.
To further improve the exhaust gas reduction performance, the system provides the engine-ECU feedback on the EGR valve opening. Thus, it effects EGR control to optimize the operating conditions of the engine.
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > COMPONENT LOCATION (EGR SYSTEM)
COMPONENT LOCATION (EGR SYSTEM)

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > EGR VALVE (DC MOTOR) CHECK
EGR VALVE (DC MOTOR) CHECK
 
 
EGR Valve Operating Noise Check
noteCarry out this check after confirming that the diagnosis code is not set. If the diagnosis code is set, the check on the EGR valve (DC motor) would not possibly be carried out correctly.
1. Start the engine and warm up. Allow the engine coolant temperature to reach above 70°C.
2. Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position. Confirm that the operating noise of the EGR valve, such as the clicking noise, can be heard 3 times when the engine is stopped.
3. If the operating noise cannot be heard, check the driving circuit of the DC motor.
noteIf the operating noise cannot be heard although the circuit is normal, There can possibly be something wrong with the EGR valve.
 
 
 
EGR Valve Operational Check
1. Prepare the power supply (5 to 9 V) for the check.
2. Remove the EGR valve (Refer to ).
3.
cautionAt this time, the power supply voltage is to be 5 V. For each voltage, current is to be applied within 5 seconds. Once the valve is opened, the voltage is not to be increased any more. The supply voltage to the motor must be a maximum of 9 V.
Connect the terminal No. 4 of the EGR valve connector with the positive terminal of the power supply of the check (5 V). Connect the terminal No. 6 of the EGR valve connector with the negative terminal of the power supply of the check.
4. Apply the power supply of 5 V to the EGR valve. Confirm that the EGR valve is opened. If the valve is not opened, increase the voltage of the power supply for the check by 1 V each time.
noteIf the EGR valve is not opened although the voltage applied to the motor is increased to 9 V, clean the EGR valve and carry out the operation check again. Despite this, replace the EGR valve if it does not operate.
5. Install the EGR valve.
 
 
 
EGR Valve Cleaning
caution
  • Do not use the solvent or cleaner because it enters to the motor and causes the operational malfunction.
  • The cleaned portion must be the valve only at the DC motor driven side from where all the circumference of the valve can be seen.
1. Remove the EGR valve (Refer to ).
2. Confirm that there is not the carbon stuck or accumulated on the EGR valve (at the DC motor driven side). If the carbon is stuck or accumulated on the valve (at the DC motor driven side), use the wire brush and so on to clean the valve.
3. Install the EGR valve.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > EGR COOLER BYPASS ACTUATOR CHECK
EGR COOLER BYPASS ACTUATOR CHECK
1. Remove the EGR pipe "B" (Refer to ).
2. Connect the hand vacuum pump with the nipple of the vacuum actuator of the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
3. Gradually applying the vacuum pressure, confirm through the hole produced by removing the EGR pipe "B" that the bypass valve shaft is normally operated. When the vacuum pressure reaches 70 kPa, confirm that the vacuum pressure is maintained.
4. If the bypass valve shaft is not operated, replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
5. Install the EGR pipe "B".
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
1. Disconnect the EGR gas temperature sensor connector.
2. Measure resistance between terminals No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value:
  • 55 to 78 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • 29 to 41 kΩ (at 0°C)
  • 17 to 23 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • 10 to 14 kΩ (at 40°C)
  • 7.1 to 8.8 kΩ (at 60°C)
  • 4.8 to 5.9 kΩ (at 80°C)
3. Remove the EGR gas temperature sensor (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N14> ).
4. Measure resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
TemperatureResistance
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the EGR gas temperature sensor.
6. Install the EGR gas temperature sensor.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SYSTEM CHECK
EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SYSTEM CHECK
1. Install the vacuum gauge through the three-way finger joint to the vacuum hose (green stripe) between the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve and the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
2. Start the engine. Confirm that the vacuum gauge display satisfies the table below.
 
Engine conditionVacuum gauge display
Cold state
(Engine coolant temperature: 40°C or less)
Vacuum exists.
  • Engine coolant temperature: 80°C or more
  • Intake air temperature: 10°C or more
  • Racing (2,500 r/min or more)
Vacuum varies.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N14> > EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SOLENOID VALVE CHECK
EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SOLENOID VALVE CHECK
1. Disconnect the vacuum hoses from the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve.
2. Disconnect the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve connector.
3. Use jumper leads to connect the solenoid valve terminal and the battery terminals.
4. Observe whether the jumper lead should be connected or disconnected to/from the battery (-) terminal, and whether the hand vacuum pump should be installed or not, and then apply negative pressure to check the air-tightness.
 
Jumper leadA nipple conditionB nipple conditionNormal condition
ConnectedInstall a hand vacuum pumpOpenNegative pressure leaks
ClosedNegative pressure maintained
Disconnected Install a hand vacuum pumpOpenNegative pressure maintained
OpenInstall a hand vacuum pumpNegative pressure leaks
5. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 29 to 35 Ω (at 20°C)
6. Replace the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve if airtightness or resistance is out of specification.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EGR VALVE AND EGR COOLER<4N14> > EGR VALVE AND EGR COOLER REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
cautionWhen the EGR cooler is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Under Skid Plate and Engine Room Under Cover Front A and B Removal (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover ).
  • Engine Coolant Draining (Refer to GROUP 14 - On-vehicle Service, Engine Coolant Replacement ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Engine Coolant Refilling (Refer to GROUP 14 - On-vehicle Service, Engine Coolant Replacement ).
  • Under Skid Plate and Engine Room Under Cover Front A and B Installation (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover ).
Removal steps
1.EGR valve connector
>>B<<2.EGR valve
>>B<<3.EGR valve gasket
>>B<<4.EGR valve pipe gasket
>>B<<5.EGR valve pipe B
>>B<<6.EGR valve pipe gasket
7.Vacuum hose connection
8.Water hose B
9.Water pipe B
10.Water hose E
11.Water hose D
>>A<<12.EGR cooler bypass actuator
>>A<<13.EGR cooler bypass actuator gasket
>>A<<14.EGR valve pipe gasket
>>A<<15.EGR valve pipe A
>>A<<16.EGR valve pipe gasket
17.Water hose A
18.Water hose H
19.Water hose K
20.Joint and engine coolant temperature sensor assembly
21.EGR cooler
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINTS
 
 
>>A<< EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR VALVE PIPE A/EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR COOLER BYPASS ACTUATOR GASKET/EGR COOLER BYPASS ACTUATOR INSTALLATION
1. Install the EGR valve pipe gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
2. Temporarily install the EGR valve pipe A to the cylinder head.
3. Install the EGR valve pipe gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
4. Install the EGR cooler bypass actuator gasket.
5. Temporarily install the EGR cooler bypass actuator to the EGR cooler.
6. Check that there is no clearance among each component. Temporarily tighten the bolts, 1, 5 and 7 as shown in the figure.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
7. Tighten each mounting bolts to the specified torque in the order as shown in the figure.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
 
 
 
>>B<< EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR VALVE PIPE B/EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR VALVE GASKET/EGR COOLER BYPASS VALVE INSTALLATION
1. Install the EGR valve pipe gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
2. Temporarily install the EGR valve pipe B to the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
3. Install the EGR valve pipe gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
4. Install the EGR valve gasket.
5. Temporarily install the EGR valve to the inlet manifold.
6. Check that there is no clearance among each component. Temporarily tighten the bolts, 1, 5 and 7 as shown in the figure.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
7. Tighten each mounting bolts to the specified torque in the order as shown in the figure.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > GENERAL INFORMATION (EGR SYSTEM)
GENERAL INFORMATION (EGR SYSTEM)
 
 
The electronically controlled EGR system consists of an EGR valve, engine-ECU and sensors.
The EGR valve aims at reducing the amount of NOx (nitric oxide) discharge that increases with the rise in the exhaust gas temperature. Also, the EGR cooler bypass system is employed. By blocking the exhaust gas flow not to pass through the EGR cooler at the engine cold state, HC (hydrocarbon) emissions are reduced. Thus, the engine-ECU optimally controls the exhaust gas temperature in accordance with the operating conditions of the engine.
To further improve the exhaust gas reduction performance, the system provides the engine-ECU feedback on the EGR valve opening. Thus, it effects EGR control to optimize the operating conditions of the engine.
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > COMPONENT LOCATION (EGR SYSTEM)
COMPONENT LOCATION

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > EGR VALVE (DC MOTOR) CHECK
EGR VALVE (DC MOTOR) CHECK
 
 
EGR Valve Operating Noise Check
noteCarry out this check after confirming that the diagnosis code is not set. If the diagnosis code is set, the check on the EGR valve (DC motor) would not possibly be carried out correctly.
1. Start the engine and warm up. Allow the engine coolant temperature to reach above 70°C.
2. Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position. Confirm that the operating noise of the EGR valve, such as the clicking noise, can be heard three times when the engine is stopped.
3. If the operating noise cannot be heard, check the driving circuit of the EGR valve (DC motor).
noteIf the operating noise cannot be heard although the circuit is normal, there can possibly be something wrong with the EGR valve.
 
 
 
EGR Valve Operational Check
1. Prepare the power supply (5 to 9 V) for the check.
2. Remove the EGR valve pipe A (Refer to ).
3. Disconnect the EGR valve connector.
4.
cautionAt this time, the power supply voltage is to be 5 V. For each voltage, current is to be applied within 5 seconds. Once the EGR valve is opened, the voltage is not to be increased any more. The supply voltage to the motor must be a maximum of 9 V.
Connect the terminal No. 4 of the EGR valve connector with the positive terminal of the power supply of the check (5 V). Connect the terminal No. 6 of the EGR valve connector with the negative terminal of the power supply of the check.
5. Apply the power supply of 5 V to the EGR valve. Confirm that the EGR valve is opened. If the EGR valve is not opened, increase the voltage of the power supply for the check by 1 V each time.
noteIf the EGR valve is not opened although the voltage applied to the motor is increased to 9 V, clean the EGR valve and carry out the operation check again. Despite this, replace the EGR valve if it does not operate.
6. Install the EGR valve pipe A.
 
 
 
EGR Valve Vacuum Actuator Check
1. Remove the EGR valve pipe B (Refer to ).
2. Connect the hand vacuum pump with the nipple of the vacuum actuator of the EGR valve.
3. Gradually applying the vacuum pressure, confirm through the hole produced by removing the EGR valve pipe B that the bypass valve shaft of the EGR valve is normally operated. When the vacuum pressure reaches 70 kPa, confirm that the vacuum pressure is maintained.
4. If the bypass valve shaft of the EGR valve is not operated, replace the EGR valve.
5. Install the EGR valve pipe B.
 
 
 
EGR Valve Cleaning
caution
  • Do not use the solvent or cleaner because it enters to the motor and causes the operational malfunction.
  • The cleaned portion must be the EGR valve only at the DC motor driven side from where all the circumference of the EGR valve can be seen. The EGR valve at the vacuum actuator driven side from where all the circumstance of the EGR valve cannot be seen results in the non-uniform cleaning. Do not clean the EGR valve at the vacuum actuator driven side because malfunctions can possibly happen such as the leak at the seat or foreign materials caught.
1. Remove the EGR valve (Refer to ).
2. Confirm that there is not the carbon stuck or accumulated on the EGR valve (at the DC motor driven side). If the carbon is stuck or accumulated on the EGR valve (at the DC motor driven side), use the wire brush and so on to clean the EGR valve.
3. Install the EGR valve.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
1. Disconnect the EGR gas temperature sensor connector.
2. Measure resistance between terminals No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value:
  • 55 to 78 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • 29 to 41 kΩ (at 0°C)
  • 17 to 23 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • 10 to 14 kΩ (at 40°C)
  • 7.1 to 8.8 kΩ (at 60°C)
  • 4.8 to 5.9 kΩ (at 80°C)
3. Remove the EGR gas temperature sensor (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N15> ).
4. Measure resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
Temperature (°C)Resistance (kΩ)
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the EGR gas temperature sensor.
6. Install the EGR gas temperature sensor.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SYSTEM CHECK
EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SYSTEM CHECK
1. Install the vacuum gauge through the three-way finger joint to the vacuum hose (green stripe) between the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve and the vacuum actuator.
2. Start the engine. Confirm that the vacuum gauge display satisfies the table below.

(Engine coolant temperature: 40°C or less)
Vacuum exists.
  • Engine coolant temperature: 80°C or more
  • Intake air temperature: 10°C or more
  • Racing (2,500 r/min or more)
Vacuum varies.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EXHAUST GAS RECIRCULATION (EGR) SYSTEM<4N15> > EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SOLENOID VALVE CHECK
EGR COOLER BYPASS CONTROL SOLENOID VALVE CHECK
1. Disconnect the vacuum hoses from the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve.
2. Disconnect the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve connector.
3. Use jumper leads to connect the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve connector terminal and the battery terminals.
4. Observe whether the jumper lead should be connected or disconnected to/from the battery (-) terminal, and whether the hand vacuum pump should be installed or not, and then apply negative pressure to check the air-tightness.
 
Jumper leadA nipple conditionB nipple conditionNormal condition
ConnectedInstall a hand vacuum pumpOpenNegative pressure leaks
ClosedNegative pressure maintained
DisconnectedInstall a hand vacuum pumpOpenNegative pressure maintained
OpenInstall a hand vacuum pumpNegative pressure leaks
5. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 29 to 35 Ω (at 20°C)
6. Replace the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve if airtightness or resistance is out of specification.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > EGR VALVE AND EGR COOLER<4N15> > EGR VALVE AND EGR COOLER REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
cautionWhen the EGR cooler is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Under Skid Plate and Engine Room Under Cover Front A and B Removal (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover ).
  • Engine Coolant Draining (Refer to GROUP 14 - On-vehicle Service, Engine Coolant Replacement ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Engine Coolant Refilling (Refer to GROUP 14 - On-vehicle Service, Engine Coolant Replacement ).
  • Under Skid Plate and Engine Room Under Cover Front A and B Installation (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover ).
Removal steps
1.Vacuum hose connection
2.EGR valve connector
3.Water hose E
4.Water hose D
5.Water hose B
6.Water pipe B
7.Water hose A
<<A>>>>B<<8.EGR valve pipe B
>>B<<9.EGR valve pipe gasket
>>A<<10.EGR valve pipe A
>>A<<11.EGR valve pipe gasket
<<A>>>>A<<12.EGR valve assembly
13.EGR valve gasket
14.EGR cooler
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> EGR VALVE PIPE B/EGR VALVE ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
When the EGR pipe B and EGR valve assembly are removed, must prevent the condensate water, oil, coolant water is not applied to the EGR motor by using waste cloth.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINTS
 
 
>>A<< EGR VALVE ASSEMBLY/EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR VALVE PIPE A INSTALLATION
1. Install each gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
2. Temporarily tighten the EGR valve assembly mounting bolts.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
3. Temporarily tighten EGR valve pipe A mounting bolts.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
4. Tighten each mounting bolts to the specified torque in the order as shown in the figure.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
 
 
 
>>B<< EGR VALVE PIPE GASKET/EGR VALVE PIPE B INSTALLATION
1. Install each gasket with its projection being positioned as shown in the figure.
2. Temporarily tighten the inlet manifold side mounting bolts.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
3. Temporarily tighten the EGR valve side mounting bolts.
Temporary tightening torque: 1.3 ± 0.7 N·m
4. Tighten the inlet manifold side mounting bolts to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
5. Tighten the EGR valve side mounting bolts to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > GENERAL INFORMATION (DPF SYSTEM)
GENERAL INFORMATION (DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER SYSTEM)
 
 
The Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) system is used to adsorb and remove the Particulate Matter (PM) contained in the exhaust gas. The engine-ECU anticipates the amount of PM accumulated in the DPF through the input signal from each sensor.
If the PM accumulates more than the standard, the engine-ECU carries out the control that automatically regenerates the DPF under certain conditions to remove the PM. At the DPF regeneration, the DPF temperature gets high and high temperature exhaust gases are given off.
 
 
System Diagram
<4N14>
<4N15>
 
 
DPF Warning Signal
 
 
<Vehicles With Mono-colour Liquid Crystal Display Type Combination Meter>
When the anticipated PM accumulation becomes larger in amount and reaches the specified level, the engine-ECU encourages the driver to drive under the driving conditions required for the DPF regeneration by illuminating the DPF warning lamp. When the PM accumulated in the DPF reaches its clogged or damaged level, the engine-ECU warns the driver that the vehicle must be brought to the workshop by illuminating the DPF warning lamp and illuminating the engine warning lamp. When the vehicle is brought into the shop with the DPF warning lamp illuminated, service the vehicle in accordance with the following procedures.
DPF warning lampEngine warning lampState and service
Being litBeing litThe engine-ECU estimates that the PM will excessively be accumulated in the DPF.
At that time, the engine-ECU should set the diagnosis codes (No. P1498 and No. P2463). Carry out the troubleshooting regarding the set diagnosis codes (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ).
noteDiagnosis code No. P2463 should be set if the engine-ECU estimates that the PM will more excessively be accumulated after No. P1498 is set and the PM will reach the level where the DPF cannot be regenerated.
Being litNot being litThe status is that the driver is advised to drive the vehicle under the driving conditions in which the DPF automatic regeneration can be carried out because it is assumed that the PM is accumulated more than the specified value in the DPF. In this case, the DPF regeneration must be carried out using one of the following two methods:
  • After the engine warm-up, the vehicle must be driven at more than 40 km/h until the DPF warning lamp is extinguished. The driving time is approximately 20 minutes. It is all right that the vehicle or the engine stops during the driving.
  • The forcible DPF regeneration must be carried out (Refer to ).
Being blinkedNot being litThe system assumes that the engine oil level is more than a predetermined. Change the engine oil and then use the M.U.T.-III to reset the learnt value on the dilution of the engine oil. [Refer to GROUP 00 - Precaution Before Service, Initialisation Procedure For Learning Value In Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System ].
noteThe engine-ECU will set diagnosis code No. P252F.
 
 
 
<Vehicles with Colour Liquid Crystal Display Type Combination Meter>
When the anticipated PM accumulation becomes larger in amount and reaches the specified level, the engine-ECU encourages the driver to drive under the driving conditions required for the DPF regeneration by showing the DPF warning mark on the multi information display. When the PM accumulated in the DPF reaches its clogged or damaged level, the engine-ECU warns the driver that the vehicle must be brought to the workshop by showing the DPF warning mark in the multi information display and illuminating the engine warning lamp. When the vehicle is brought into the shop with the DPF warning mark shown, service the vehicle in accordance with the following procedures.
DPF warning markEngine warning lampState and service
ShownBeing litThe engine-ECU estimates that the PM will excessively be accumulated in the DPF.
At that time, the engine-ECU should set the diagnosis codes (No. P1498 and No. P2463). Carry out the troubleshooting regarding the set diagnosis codes (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ).
noteDiagnosis code No. P2463 should be set if the engine-ECU estimates that the PM will more excessively be accumulated after No. P1498 is set and the PM will reach the level where the DPF cannot be regenerated.
ShownNot being litThe status is that the driver is advised to drive the vehicle under the driving conditions in which the DPF automatic regeneration can be carried out because it is assumed that the PM is accumulated more than the specified value in the DPF. In this case, the DPF regeneration must be carried out using one of the following two methods:
  • After the engine warm-up, the vehicle must be driven at more than 40 km/h until the DPF warning lamp is extinguished. The driving time is approximately 20 minutes. It is all right that the vehicle or the engine stops during the driving.
  • The forcible DPF regeneration must be carried out (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > COMPONENT LOCATION (DPF SYSTEM)
COMPONENT LOCATION (DPF SYSTEM)

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > FORCIBLE DPF REGENERATION<4N14>
FORCIBLE DPF REGENERATION <4N14>
warning
  • When the forcible DPF regeneration is carried out, confirm that no people or no combustible material is within its vicinity. If people or combustible material is around the muffler, serious injury or damage such as heat injury or fires may occur because high temperature exhaust gases are put out.
  • Perform the forcible DPF regeneration in a well-ventilated and flat place when the vehicle is stopped (If perform the forcible DPF regeneration indoors, surely carry out enforced ventilation).
  • If the engine warning lamp is lit, the DPF system might be abnormal. Carry out the inspection chart for diagnosis code, and then perform the forcible DPF regeneration (Refer to , GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart For Diagnosis codes).
note
  • If white smoke or particular smell appear during the forcible DPF regeneration, this does not indicate an abnormality.
  • When the engine warning lamp illuminates with the DPF warning mark shown in the multi information display, the forcible regeneration of the DPF must be carried out.
  • If the forcible DPF regeneration is performed while the DPF warning mark is displayed due to the accumulation of PM, the DPF warning mark disappears when the forcible DPF regeneration is completed normally.
1. Set the vehicle to the pre-inspection condition.
2. Perform ammonia purge (Refer to ). After ammonia purge is complete, leave the vehicle with the ignition switch OFF until diesel fuel system data list Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor falls below 115°C (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Data List Reference Table).
note
  • There is no problem with not performing ammonia purge. However, a strong ammonia odour may be generated during the forcible DPF regeneration if ammonia purge is not performed.
  • Although it depends on the surrounding environment, it takes approximately 38 minutes for the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor to fall below 115°C after ammonia purge is complete.
cautionConnection and disconnection of M.U.T.-III should be always performed with the ignition switch turned to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
3. After the ignition switch is in "LOCK" (OFF) position, connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
4. Start the engine and let it run at idle.
5. Select "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
6. From function menu on M.U.T.-III, select "Special Function".
7. From "Special Function", select "DPF regeneration".
cautionIf the forcible regeneration of the DPF is carried out while the accumulated amount of the PM in the DPF exceeds the limit, the forcible regeneration might not be correctly completed. This could be caused by the detection in the DPF system malfunction. Carry out the check procedure for the diagnosis code and solve the malfunction (Refer to , GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart For Diagnosis Codes).
8. Perform Item No. 34: DPF Regeneration.
noteCarrying out the forcible DPF regeneration increases the engine speed 1,500 to 2,000 r/min (the temperature increases within the DPF and is maintained at approximately 600°C).
9. When the DPF regeneration is started, disconnect the special tool V.C.I.-Lite USB cable (MB992747/MB992748) or M.U.T.-III USB cable (MB991827) from the personal computer, and then connect it again.
noteWhen the V.C.I.-Lite USB cable or M.U.T.-III USB cable is disconnected, the System Select Screen appears.
10. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen.
11. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function."
12. From Special Function Screen, select "DPF regeneration."
13. Carry out Item No.1 Start fixed-quantity Urea injection from DPF regeneration Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
noteDo not disconnect the M.U.T.-III from the diagnosis connector during the forcible DPF regeneration.
14. When the engine speed returns to the normal idle operation, check whether the DPF warning mark is displayed.
note
  • When performed for about 25 minutes, the forcible DPF regeneration automatically stops. Depressing the accelerator pedal during the regeneration, however, can cancel the forcible DPF regeneration.
  • Only when the DPF warning mark is not displayed, carry out Step 15, and then go to Step 21.
15. Let the engine idle until the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out. After the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out, turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
noteWhen the engine is run at idle for 15 minutes, the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out.
16. When the DPF warning mark does not go out, carry out the following procedures again.
(1) Leave the vehicle with the ignition switch OFF until diesel fuel system data list Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor falls below 115°C (Refer to GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Data List Reference Table).
(2) Carry out step 8 to step 14.
17. When the DPF warning mark goes out, let the engine idle until the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out. After the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out, turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
noteWhen the engine is run at idle for 15 minutes, the diesel preheat indicator lamp goes out.
18. Check diesel fuel system data list Item No. 328: DPF regeneration request (Refer to GROUP 13C - Troubleshooting, Data List Reference Table).
noteOnly if the check result is ON (during DPF regeneration request), ask the customer to perform the DPF regeneration by driving when returning the vehicle. If it is difficult for the customer to perform the DPF regeneration, perform the forcible DPF regeneration again from Step 16.
19. Turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position and then remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > FORCIBLE DPF REGENERATION<4N15>
FORCIBLE DPF REGENERATION <4N15>
warning
  • When the forcible DPF regeneration is carried out, confirm that no people or no combustible material is within its vicinity. If people or combustible material is around the muffler, serious injury or damage such as heat injury or fires may occur because high temperature exhaust gases are put out.
  • Perform the forcible DPF regeneration in a well-ventilated and flat place when the vehicle is stopped (If perform the forcible DPF regeneration indoors, surely carry out enforced ventilation).
  • If the engine warning lamp is lit, the DPF system might be abnormal. Carry out the inspection chart for diagnosis code, and then perform the forcible DPF regeneration (Refer to , GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart For Diagnosis codes).
noteIf white smoke or particular smell appear during the forcible DPF regeneration, this does not indicate an abnormality.
1. Set the vehicle to the pre-inspection condition.
cautionConnection and disconnection of M.U.T.-III should be always performed with the ignition switch turned to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
2. Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
3. Start the engine and let it run at idle.
4. Select "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
5. From function menu on M.U.T.-III, select "Special Function".
6. From "Special Function", select "DPF regeneration".
cautionIf the forcible regeneration of the DPF is carried out while the accumulated amount of the PM in the DPF exceeds the limit, the forcible regeneration might not be correctly completed. This could be caused by the detection in the DPF system malfunction. Carry out the check procedure for the diagnosis code and solve the malfunction (Refer to , GROUP 13A - Troubleshooting, Inspection Chart For Diagnosis Codes).
7. Perform Item No. 34: DPF Regeneration.
note
  • Carrying out the forcible DPF regeneration increases the engine speed 1,500 to 2,000 r/min (the temperature increases within the DPF and is maintained at approximately 600°C).
  • When performed for about 25 minutes, the forcible DPF regeneration automatically stops. Depressing the accelerator pedal during the regeneration, however, can cancel the forcible DPF regeneration.
  • If the DPF regeneration is carried out while the DPF warning mark <vehicles with colour liquid crystal display type combination meter> or DPF warning lamp <vehicles with mono-colour liquid crystal display type combination meter> is illuminated or blinked due to the accumulated PM, the DPF warning mark <vehicles with colour liquid crystal display type combination meter> or DPF warning lamp <vehicles with mono-colour liquid crystal display type combination meter> is turned off as soon as the forcible regeneration is correctly completed.
8. Turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position and then remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > NO. 1 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
NO. 1 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
1. Disconnect the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 75 to 190 kΩ (at 20°C)
3. Remove the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor (Refer to ).
4. Measure the resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
TemperatureResistance
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor.
6. Install the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > NO. 2 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
No. 2 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR (CATALYST TEMPERATURE) CHECK
1. Disconnect the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 75 to 190 kΩ (at 20°C)
3. Remove the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) (Refer to ).
4. Measure the resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
TemperatureResistance
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature).
6. Install the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM > NO. 3 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
No. 3 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR (DPF TEMPERATURE) CHECK
1. Disconnect the No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature) connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 75 to 190 kΩ (at 20°C)
3. Remove the No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature) (Refer to ).
4. Measure the resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
TemperatureResistance
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature).
6. Install the No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature).
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
caution
  • When the DPF is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
  • When the DPF is replaced, carry out the forcible DPF regeneration after initialising the learning value (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
  • When the DPF is replaced, carry out the each operation using the M.U.T.-III as indicated in the section "Action to be take when urea SCR system related parts are replaced" (Refer to ). <4N14>
The DPF is integrated with the catalytic converter. The removal and installation is the same as the catalytic converter (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM SENSORS > DIESEL PARTICULATE FILTER (DPF) SYSTEM SENSORS REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
caution
  • When the exhaust differential pressure sensor is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
  • When the exhaust differential pressure sensor is replaced, perform the forcible DPF regeneration after learning value in DPF system (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
  • When the No. 1, No. 2 or No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor is replaced, perform the forcible DPF regeneration (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
Pre-removal and Post-installation Operations
  • Engine Upper Cover Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 13A - Throttle Body ).
  • Under Skid Plate and Engine Room Under Cover Front A and B Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover ).
Removal steps
1.No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector connection
2.No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
3.No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector connection
4.No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor
5.No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector
6.No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor
7.Bracket <2WD>
8.Exhaust differential pressure sensor connector
9.Exhaust pressure hose
10.Exhaust pressure hose
11.Exhaust differential pressure sensor
12.Exhaust differential pressure sensor bracket
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > PRECAUTIONS WHEN HANDLING/SERVICING Adblue
PRECAUTIONS WHEN HANDLING/SERVICING Adblue™
caution
  • Use urea water which obtains the AdBlue™ trade mark.
    • AdBlue™: trademark of the Verband der Automobilindustrie e.V. (VDA).
  • Since AdBlue™ freezes at -11°C or less, service under the condition that AdBlue™ does not freeze.
  • If any AdBlue™ gets on painted surfaces, wash it off immediately with clean water.
  • If the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
  • Put the disconnected pipes and connectors in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
<When painting the plate>
  • When the urea tank assembly temperature is more than 60°C, AdBlue™ rapidly deteriorates. Remove the urea tank assembly before servicing. (When using a panel heater or spot heater in a paint booth, the same procedure must be done).
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA FEED TUBE DISCONNECTION (HOW TO REDUCE PRESSURIZED UREA PRESSURE)
REDUCE UREA PRESSURE IN PRESSURISED UREA FEED TUBES
warningWhen removing the urea feed tube, etc., release urea pressure to prevent urea spray.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
1. Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Test".
6. Carry out the "Item No. 1: Line emptying test" from Test Screen.
7. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > AdBlue REFILL
AdBlue™ REFILL
caution
  • Do not refill the urea tank with diesel exhaust fluid other than AdBlue™.
  • If any AdBlue™ gets on painted surfaces, wash it off immediately with clean water.
  • If the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
 
 
<When replenishing by confirming the maximum refill quantity by the M.U.T.-III>
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position (But do not start the engine).
3. Check "Item No. 64: Urea tank remaining volume" from the M.U.T.-III data list.
4. Confirm the maximum refill quantity in the table below according to the value read out in Step 3.
Item No. 64: Urea tank remaining volume (%)*1Item No. 8: Urea tank level (mm)*2Remaining distance (km)*3Maximum refill quantity (L)*4
5.0540.6021
5.72545145.3420.855
7.6955574.49620.462
11.3661.51,376.02419.728
15.49602,278.01618.902
19.88653,236.79218.024
24.42704,228.32817.116
33.76806,268.18415.248
43.21908,332.06413.358
52.7710010,419.96811.446
71.9412014,606.6967.612
note
  • *1: This value will not be 100% even if the urea tank is full, because the upper limit for the reading of the urea tank level sensor is set to 100%.
  • *2: The maximum refill quantity can also be confirmed according to the value of M.U.T.-III data list item No. 8: Urea tank level.
  • *3: This is only for reference because the urea consumption amount varies depending on the driving conditions.
  • *4: It is no problem if the refill quantity is less than this value because this is the maximum refill quantity.
5. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
6. Replenish AdBlue™ via the AdBlue™ refill port by considering the maximum refill quantity which you confirmed in Step 4.
note
  • Only when the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning is displayed on the combination meter, proceed to Step 7.
  • When rechecking the maximum refill quantity after replenishing AdBlue™, be sure to perform Step 7 through Step 12 before the recheck.
7. Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
8. Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position (But do not start the engine).
9. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
10. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
11. From Special Function Screen, select "Reset".
12. Carry out "Item No. 1: Urea tank level" from Reset Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
13. Check that the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning has disappeared from the combination meter.
noteIf the refill quantity at one time is 3 litres or more, the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning can be turned off without performing the urea tank level reset. The warning can be turned off by performing the following procedure. Stop the vehicle on a level surface, and turn the ignition switch from "LOCK" (OFF) to "ON" (do not start the engine). Then, leave the vehicle for approximately 5 minutes or more.
14. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
<When the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning is displayed on the combination meter>
1. Confirm the travelable distance of the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning displayed on the combination meter.
2. By referring to the table below, confirm the maximum refill quantity according to the travelable distance.
<k/m>
Travelable distance displayMaximum refill quantity (L)*Travelable distance displayMaximum refill quantity (L)*
2,400 km19.84400 km20.795
2,100 km19.945200 km20.895
1,800 km20.095100 km20.945
1,500 km20.24560 km20.965
1,200 km20.39540 km20.975
900 km20.54520 km20.985
600 km20.69510 km20.99
<mile>
Travelable distance displayMaximum refill quantity (L)*Travelable distance displayMaximum refill quantity (L)*
1,500 mile19.792300 mile20.752
1,300 mile19.952200 mile20.832
1,100 mile20.112100 mile20.912
900 mile20.27260 mile20.944
700 mile20.43240 mile20.96
500 mile20.59220 mile20.976
400 mile20.67210 mile20.984
note*: It is no problem if the refill quantity is less than this value because this is the maximum refill quantity. However, the refill quantity at one time should be more than 3 litres because the travelable distance will not be updated if the refill quantity is 3 litres or less.
3. Replenish AdBlue™ via the AdBlue™ refill port by considering the maximum refill quantity which you confirmed in Step 2.
4. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position, and leave the vehicle for approximately 5 minutes.
5. Check that the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning has disappeared from the combination meter.
6. If the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning does not go out, turn off the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning by the following procedures.
(1)
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position (But do not start the engine).
(3) Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
(4) From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
(5) From Special Function Screen, select "Reset".
(6) Carry out "Item No. 1: Urea tank level" from Reset Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
(7) Check that the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning has disappeared from the combination meter.
noteIf the refill quantity at one time is 3 litres or more, the AdBlue™ remaining amount warning can be turned off without performing the urea tank level reset. The warning can be turned off by performing the following procedure. Stop the vehicle on a level surface, and turn the ignition switch from "LOCK" (OFF) to "ON" (do not start the engine). Then, leave the vehicle for approximately 5 minutes or more.
(8) After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > AdBlue CHANGE
AdBlue™ CHANGE
caution
  • Do not refill the urea tank with diesel exhaust fluid other than AdBlue™.
  • If any AdBlue™ gets on painted surfaces, wash it off immediately with clean water.
  • If the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
1. Disconnect the urea filler hose C assembly from the urea tank.
2. Insert a hand pump to the urea tank assembly, and drain AdBlue™ as much as possible.
3. Remove the urea tank assembly from the vehicle (Refer to ).
4. Open the reverse flow prevention valve of the urea tank assembly with a bar or the like. Then, tilt the tank to let the AdBlue™ flow out.
5. Install the urea tank assembly and urea filler hose C assembly to the original position.
6. Refill the AdBlue™ (Refer to ).
noteIn order to fill up the empty urea tank, refill approximately 16 litres of AdBlue™.
7. Reset the urea tank level (Refer to ).
8. Execute the urea SCR system test 3 times or more to bleed the air (Refer to ).
note
  • Although the test may be interrupted, be sure to execute the test 3 times or more. If the test is not executed, the air may not be bled from the urea pump and the urea line tube, and a diagnosis code No. P20E8 may be set.
  • If the test is completed successfully at the third time or thereafter, air bleeding is completed.
  • When the urea tank assembly is replaced (when the urea pump is new), it is enough to perform this procedure only once.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > AMMONIA PURGE
AMMONIA PURGE
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Start the engine and run at idle.
3. Select "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From MPI/GDI/DIESEL Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Ammonia purge".
6. Carry out the "Item No. 56: Ammonia purge" from Ammonia purge Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
noteThe idle speed increases while ammonia purge is in progress (approximately 2,200 r/min).
7. Return to System select Screen.
8. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
9. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
10. From Special Function Screen, select "Ammonia purge".
11. Carry out the "Item No. 1: Stop Urea injection" from Ammonia purge Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
note
  • Do not disconnect the M.U.T.-III from the diagnosis connector during the ammonia purge.
  • When the ammonia purge is completed, the value of the M.U.T.-III data list item No. 76: Estimated ammonia load decreases and smaller value is set.
12. Confirm that the idle operation returns to the normal engine speed, and then turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
noteWhen 30 minutes pass after ammonia purge is performed, the engine speed returns to the normal idle operation.
13. Remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > ACTION TO BE TAKEN WHEN UREA SCR SYSTEM RELATED PARTS ARE REPLACED
ACTION TO BE TAKEN WHEN UREA SCR SYSTEM RELATED PARTS ARE REPLACED
 
 
After urea SCR system related parts are replaced, execute each command of the M.U.T.-III as shown in the table below.
Operation typeImplementation items
DCU replacement
  • Write learned value (Changed ECU)
  • Urea SCR system test
  • Reset (Urea tank level)*1
Exhaust centre pipe (integrated with SCR) replacementInitialisation (Item No. 1: SCR catalyst exchange)
Urea tank assembly replacement
  • Urea SCR system test
  • Reset (Urea tank level)*1
Urea injector assembly replacement
  • Urea SCR system test
  • Initialisation (Item No. 7: Urea injector exchange)
Urea line tube replacementUrea SCR system test
AdBlue™ refillReset (Urea tank level)*1
AdBlue™ change
  • Urea SCR system test*2
  • Reset (Urea tank level)*1
No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor replacementInitialisation [Item No. 2: NOx sensor (UP) exchange]
No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor replacementInitialisation [Item No. 3: NOx sensor (DOWN) exchange]
Exhaust muffler PM sensor replacementInitialization (Item No. 4: PM sensor exchange)
Catalytic converter assembly (integrated with catalytic converter and DPF) replacement
  • Initialisation (Item No. 5: Oxi catalyst exchange)
  • Initialisation (Item No. 6: DPF catalyst exchange)
note
  • *1: The urea tank level can be reset without using the M.U.T.-III by leaving the vehicle on a level surface with the ignition switch to the "ON" position for approximately 5 minutes. However, if the amount of change in the urea tank level is less than 3 litres, the urea tank level needs to be reset by using the M.U.T.-III.
  • *2: Only when AdBlue™ is completely drained from the urea tank, execute the urea SCR system test 3 times.
 
 
 
Implementation Method
 
 
DCU Learning Value Writing
If the DCU is replaced, follow the procedure below to save the values stored in the old DCU and then write them to the new DCU.
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
3. Select "DCU" from System select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. Select "Write learned value(Changed ECU)" from Special Function Screen.
6. Select "Learned value Read&save" from Write learned value Screen.
7. Press "OK" to store the initial learning value file.
note
  • When the learning value file is appropriately stored, "Learned value Save Complete" is shown on the screen of the M.U.T.-III.
  • The file is named as "LND + date + time" which is based on the time when the file is imported to a personal computer.
8. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, replace the DCU (Refer to ).
9. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
10. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
11. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
12. Select "Write learned value(Changed ECU)" from Special Function Screen.
13. Select "Saved learned value writing" from Write learned value Screen.
14. Select the initial learning value file stored during Step 7 to write the initial learning value.
note
  • Use only the initial learning value file stored during Step 7 without using any other files.
  • Make sure that the selected file is correct by checking the file name (saved date), then carry out the procedure.
  • When the initial learning value is appropriately written, "Learned value writing Completed." is shown on the screen of the M.U.T.-III.
15. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
Urea SCR System Test
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Test".
6. Carry out "Item No. 5 SCR system test" from Test Screen of the M.U.T.-III when all the conditions below are satisfied.
  • Data list item No. 3: SCR catalyst temperature is 80°C or less.
  • Data list item No. 5: SCR state machine is not ''Purge''.
  • Data list item No. 7: Urea tank temperature is between 0°C and 50°C.
  • Data list item No. 8: Urea tank level is 42.25 mm or more.
noteIf the test is interrupted, check whether a diagnosis code is set (Refer to ).
7. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
Reset (Urea Tank Level)
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Reset".
6. Carry out "Item No. 1 Urea tank level" from Reset Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
7. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
Initialisation (Each Item)
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Initialization".
6. Select the item you want to initialise from Initialization Screen of the M.U.T.-III, and execute it.
7. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > SYSTEM CONFIGURATION DIAGRAM
SYSTEM CONFIGURATION DIAGRAM
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > COMPONENT LOCATION (UREA SCR SYSTEM)
COMPONENT LOCATION

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA SCR RELAY CONTINUITY CHECK
UREA SCR RELAY CONTINUITY CHECK
Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Inspection .
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA TANK CHECK
UREA TANK CHECK
 
 
Check The Heater Resistance
1. Remove the urea tank protector (right side lower) and urea tank protector (pump and tube) (Refer to ).
2.
cautionPut the disconnected connector in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
Disconnect the urea pump module connector.
3. Measure the resistance between terminals No. 11 and No. 12 at the urea tank connector.
Standard value: 1.2 to 1.9 Ω (at 25°C)
4. If resistance is outside the standard value, replace the urea tank assembly.
5. Connect the urea pump module connector, and install the urea tank protector (pump and tube) and urea tank protector (right side lower).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA PUMP CHECK
UREA PUMP CHECK
 
 
Operation Check
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
5. From Special Function Screen, select "Test".
6. Execute "Item No. 1 Line emptying test" on the test screen and depressurise the urea feed tube.
7. Remove the urea tank protector (right side lower) and urea tank protector (pump and tube) (Refer to ).
8.
caution
  • When disconnecting the urea line tube, follow the steps below to prevent AdBlue™ leaks.
    • If solid AdBlue™ is adhered to the connection, wipe it off with a wet cloth.
    • Clean the mud around the urea line tube C.
    • Put the disconnected urea line tube in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
  • If the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
Disconnect the urea line tube C from the urea pump.
9. Execute "Item No. 3 Urea pumping and injection test" on the test screen.
10. Check the status of the AdBlue™ discharged from the urea pump.
Standard value: AdBlue™ is discharged from the urea pump.
11. Press the stop button to terminate the urea pumping and injection test.
noteIf the urea pumping and injection test is continued, the DCU determines that the pressure has dropped and the test will be terminated abnormally even if the system is normal.
12. If the AdBlue™ is not discharged from the urea pump, replace the urea pump (Refer to ).
13. Connect the urea line tube C, and install the urea tank protector (pump and tube) and urea tank protector (right side lower).
 
 
 
Check The Pump Resistance
1. Remove the urea tank protector (right side lower) and urea tank protector (pump and tube) (Refer to ).
2.
cautionPut the disconnected connector in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
Disconnect the urea pump module connector.
3. Supply pump: Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2 at the urea pump module connector.
Standard value: 3.62 to 4.51 Ω (at 25°C)
4. Back flow pump: Measure the resistance between terminal No. 3 and No. 4 at the urea pump module connector.
Standard value: 3.62 to 4.51 Ω (at 25°C)
5. If resistance is outside the standard value, replace the urea pump (Refer to ).
6. Connect the urea pump module connector, and install the urea tank protector (pump and tube) and urea tank protector (right side lower).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA FEED TUBE HEATER CHECK
UREA LINE TUBE HEATER CHECK
 
 
Check The Heater Resistance
Remove the urea tank protector (right side lower) and urea tank protector (pump and tube) (Refer to ).
1.
cautionPut the disconnected connector in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
Disconnect the urea heater tube connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminals.
Standard value: 2.93 to 3.57 Ω (at 20°C)
3. If the resistance is deviates from the standard value, replace the urea line tube A, B or/and C.
4. Connect the urea heater tube connector, and install the urea tank protector (pump and tube) and urea tank protector (right side lower).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR SYSTEM<4N14> > UREA INJECTOR CHECK
UREA INJECTOR ASSEMBLY CHECK
 
 
Measurement of Resistance Between Terminals
1.
cautionPut the disconnected connector in a plastic bag respectively to prevent dust from adhering to them.
Disconnect the urea injector assembly connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminals.
Standard value: 11.4 to 12.6 Ω (at 20°C)
3. Measure the resistance between urea injector body and either terminal No. 1 or terminal No. 2 of the connector at the urea injector assembly (check short to earth in the internal circuit of the urea injector).
Standard value: No continuity
4. If the resistance is deviates from the standard value, replace the urea injector assembly.
5. Connect the urea injector assembly connector.
 
 
 
Check The Urea Pressure
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Warm up the engine until data list item No.15: Supply pump power stage status is "ON".
3. Check the data list item No. 6: SCR sub state machine and item No. 9: Modeled urea pressure.
Standard value: SCR sub state machine reaches to "Metering control", and Modeled urea pressure reaches to "5,000 to 6,500 hPa".
4. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
 
 
 
Check The Urea Injector Assembly Condition
1. Remove the urea injector assembly from the catalytic converter without disconnecting the urea injector assembly connector and the urea line tube A from the urea injector assembly (Refer to ).
2.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
3. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
4. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
5. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
6. From Special Function Screen, select "Test".
7. Carry out the "Item No. 3: Urea pumping and injection test" from Test Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
noteIt takes approximately 30 seconds until the AdBlue™ is injected from the urea injector assembly after the urea pumping and injection test is performed because it takes time until the urea line tube is filled with the AdBlue™.
8.
cautionIf the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
Check the injection status of the urea injector assembly.
Standard value: The AdBlue™ is injected from each injection port of the urea injector assembly equally.
9. Stop "Item No. 3: Urea pumping and injection test".
10. If AdBlue™ is not equally injected from each injection port of the urea injector assembly, replace the urea injector assembly.
11. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
12. Install the urea injector assembly in the original places.
 
 
 
Check The Urea Leaks
1. Remove the urea injector assembly from the catalytic converter without disconnecting the urea injector assembly connector and the urea line tube A from the urea injector assembly (Refer to ).
2.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
3. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position (but do not start the engine).
4. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
5. From DCU Screen, select "Special Function".
6. From Special Function Screen, select "Test".
7. Carry out the "Item No. 2: Urea leak test" from Test Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
8.
cautionIf the AdBlue™ is adhered to the vehicle, wipe the area with a wet cloth.
Check for leakage from the urea injector nozzle and urea line tube.
Normal condition: During the urea leak test, the AdBlue™ does not leak from the urea injector nozzle or urea line tube.
9. If AdBlue™ is leaking from each injection nozzle or urea line tube, replace the urea injector assembly or urea line tube.
10. After turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, remove the M.U.T.-III.
11. Install the urea injector assembly in the original places.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > DIAGNOSIS TROUBLESHOOTING FLOW
DIAGNOSIS TROUBLESHOOTING FLOW
caution
  • When the urea SCR system warning screen is displayed on the combination meter, drive the vehicle to make the DCU determine whether the system is normal after carrying out repairs. Even if the diagnosis code is erased by the M.U.T.-III, the warning screen will not disappear until the DCU determines that the system is normal.
  • If engine restart is prohibited due to an abnormality in the urea SCR system, the engine can be restarted by releasing the engine restart prohibition state using the M.U.T.-III (Refer to ).
Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Contents of Troubleshooting .
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > DIAGNOSIS FUNCTION
DIAGNOSIS FUNCTION
 
 
Urea SCR System Warning Screen/Indicator, Engine Warning Lamp
When the abnormal condition occurs with respect to the items of urea SCR system shown in the table, the warning screen will display, the warning indicator will blink or the engine warning lamp will illuminate. The warning indicator flashes interlocking with the warning screen display. If the warning screen continues to be displayed on the information screen or if the engine warning lamp remains illuminated, check the (provisional) diagnosis code is set.
The warning screen is displayed once the system is determined to be defective, and it will continue to be displayed until the DCU determines that the system is normal. When the diagnosis code is erased by the M.U.T.-III, the engine warning lamp will go off, but the warning screen will not disappear.
In addition, when the warning screen is displayed, the countdown of the travelable distance starts at the same time. If you keep driving with the warning screen displayed until the travelable distance becomes 0 km, the engine restart is prohibited. If the ignition switch is "ON" position, driving can be continued even when the engine restart is prohibited. However, the engine cannot be started once the ignition switch is turned to the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
 
 
 
Urea SCR System Warning Screen/Indicator, Engine Warning Lamp Inspection Items
Diagnosis code No.ItemWarning screen display/warning indicator blinking*1Engine warning lamp illuminating

note
  • *1: The warning indicator flashes at the same time as when the warning screen is displayed.
  • After the DCU has detected a malfunction, the engine warning lamp illuminates when the same malfunction is re-detected 2 more drive cycles. However, for items marked with a "*2" in the diagnosis code number column, the engine warning lamp illuminates only on the first detection of the malfunction.
  • *3: Applicable only for open circuit and short circuit to body earth.
  • *4: Applicable only for short circuit to power supply.
  • *5: Applicable only for high-temperature abnormality of the pump.
 
 
Method of Reading and Erasing Diagnosis Codes
Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Diagnosis Function .
 
 
 
Inspection with M.U.T.-III Data List and Actuator Teat
Reading data list or performing an actuator test using M.U.T.-III enables you to check the vehicle body harnesses and components for abnormalities. Sensor input or output to the actuator can be displayed in numerical values or graphs in the data list while in the actuator test the actuator can be forced to drive (ON/OFF driving in the specified time).
 
 
Diagnosis procedure
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect M.U.T.-III to perform inspection with the data list and actuator test function.
2. If any abnormality is found, inspect and repair vehicle body harnesses and components.
3. After repair, check that input and output have returned to normal.
4. If a failure code which is caused by inspection and repair work is generated, erase the failure code.
5. Disconnect M.U.T.-III and perform a test run to check that the malfunction phenomenon is resolved.
 
 
 
 
Provisional Diagnosis Code Confirmed
If detecting the malfunction during the first drive cycle, the DCU temporarily sets the diagnosis code as the provisional diagnosis code. If detecting the same malfunction during the 2 more drive cycles, the DCU determines that the malfunction exists. The DCU sets the diagnosis code.
On the M.U.T.-III, it is possible to display the set provisional diagnosis code which the DCU had detected during the first drive cycle. This makes it possible to confirm in 1 drive cycle whether the malfunction could happen again after the repair.
 
 
Confirmation method
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
After the ignition switch is in "LOCK" (OFF) position, connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
3. Select "DCU" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. Select "Special Function" from DCU Screen.
5. Select "Provisional DTCs" from Special Function Screen.
 
 
 
 
How to Release the Engine Restart Prohibition Status
When the vehicle is driven for a predetermined distance after the warning screen of the urea SCR system is displayed on the combination meter, the engine restart is prohibited. When driving the vehicle to make the DCU determine whether the system is normal after carrying out repairs, the engine can be restarted by following the steps below.
noteWhen this operation is executed, the travelable distance is reset to 50 km. Therefore, the command needs to be executed only when the engine restart is prohibited.
 
 
Releasing Procedure
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
After the ignition switch is in "LOCK" (OFF) position, connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position.
3. Select "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" from System Select Screen of the M.U.T.-III.
4. Select "Special Function" from MPI/GDI/DIESEL Screen.
5. Select "Initialization" from Special Function Screen.
6. Carry out the "Item No. 54: SCR System Repair Completed" from Initialization Screen.
 
 
 
 
Freeze Frame Data
When the DCU detects a malfunction and sets a diagnosis code, it also stores a current status of the urea SCR system.
This function is called "Freeze frame data." By analysing this "Freeze frame data" with the M.U.T.-III, an effective troubleshooting can be performed.
The display items of freeze frame data are shown below.
 
 
 
Display Item List
Item No.Data itemUnit·Condition
1Ignition statusON or OFF
2Battery voltagemV
3SCR catalyst temperature°C
4Total distance since first startm
5SCR state machineInitial, Standby, No pressure control, Pressure control, Pressure reduction, Key OFF, Purge, Service test, Plausibility check, or Engine stop (AS&G)
6SCR sub state machine-, Pre-Emptying, Emptying, Shutoff waiting, Pressure build-up, Ventilation, Metering control, Engine stop (AS&G), Purge (17), Purge (18), Purge (19), Purge (20), Purge (21), Purge (22), Purge (27), Pressure reduce (28), Pressure reduce (29), Pressure reduce (30), Pressure reduce (31) or Pressure reduce (32)
7Urea tank temperature°C
8Urea tank levelmm
9Modeled Urea pressurehPa
10Desired fuel injection quantitymg/hub
11Engine speedr/min
12Vehicle speedkm/h
13Urea tank heater power stage statusON or OFF
14Pressure line heater power stage statusON or OFF
15Supply pump power stage statusON or OFF
16Back flow pump power stage statusON or OFF
17Defrost check (Tank/Line)Completed or Not completed
18Urea injector power stage (Duty)%
19Actual dosed quantity (Feedback)mg/s
20Exhaust gas mass flowkg/h

17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > CODE NO. P0606 ECU Fail (Microcomputer)
Code No. P0606: ECU Fail (Microcomputer)
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The DCU sets diagnosis code No. P0606 when it detects a CPU malfunction.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Ignition switch is "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • When DCU detects a CPU malfunction.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
Failed DCU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0606 set?
Replace the DCU (Refer to ).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > CODE NO. P062F EEPROM Fail
Code No. P062F: EEPROM Fail
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The DCU sets diagnosis code No. P062F when it detects a EEPROM malfunction.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Ignition switch is "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • When DCU detects a EEPROM malfunction.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
Failed DCU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P062F set?
Replace the DCU (Refer to ).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > CODE NO. P06A8 Sensor Reference Voltage "C" Circuit Range/Performance
Code No. P06A8: Sensor Reference Voltage "C" Circuit Range/Performance
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The DCU sets diagnosis code No. P06A8 when it detects a DCU internal circuit malfunction.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Ignition switch is "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • When DCU detects an ASIC output voltage monitor malfunction.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
Failed DCU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P06A8 set?
Replace the DCU (Refer to ).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > CODE NO. P06EA NOx Sensor Processor Performance(Bank 1 Sensor 1)
Code No. P06EA: No. 1 NOx Sensor Processor Performance
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The DCU sets a diagnosis code No. P06EA when the operation ratio of the No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor is 30% or less.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Sensing by the No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor is possible or at least 180 seconds have passed since the heater was energised.
  • Engine is running.
  • The change in the AdBlue™ injection amount is 6 mg/st or less.
  • The excess air ratio is 1 or more (lean state).
Judgement Criterion
  • The operation ratio of the No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor remains to be 30% or less for 45 seconds or more (determined every 15 seconds).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor
  • Failed DCU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
After replacing the No. 1 exhaust muffler NOx sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Drive the vehicle for at least 1 minute after the engine is warmed up until M.U.T.-III data list item No. 21: NOx sensor (UP) heater release status has changed to "ON."
(3) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P06EA set?
Replace the DCU (Refer to ).
The check is end.
 
 
17 -ENGINE AND EMISSION CONTROL > EMISSION CONTROL <DIESEL> > UREA SCR TROUBLESHOOTING<4N14> > CODE NO. P06EB NOx Sensor Processor Performance(Bank 1 Sensor 2)
Code No. P06EB: No. 2 NOx Sensor Processor Performance
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The DCU sets a diagnosis code No. P06EB when the operation ratio of the No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor is 30% or less.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Sensing by the No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor is possible or at least 180 seconds have passed since the heater was energised.
  • Engine is running.
  • The change in the AdBlue™ injection amount is 6 mg/st or less.
  • The excess air ratio is 1 or more (lean state).
Judgement Criterion
  • The operation ratio of the No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor remains to be 30% or less for 45 seconds or more (determined every 15 seconds).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor
  • Failed DCU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the No. 2 exhaust muffler NOx sensor
